How One PMM Team Built an AI Agent That's Changing Everything

Jacob Brass and his cross-functional team at SAP created an Agentic AI Chatbot that's revolutionizing how product marketing supports the field.

By Chris O'Hara ¬∑ February 12, 2026 ¬∑ 7 min read

If you've ever spent your afternoon answering the same SKU question for the fifth time, or explaining approval workflows to yet another sales rep, you know the pain. Jacob Brass knew it too. So he did something about it.

At SAP, like at most enterprise software companies, Product Marketing Managers and Product Managers serve as the connective tissue between product development and the field. They're the experts‚Äîthe people who know which SKUs do what, which solutions can be bundled, and why certain deals need special approval. That expertise makes them invaluable. It also makes them a bottleneck.

"The challenge was clear," explains the team's project documentation. "Product Marketing Managers and Product Managers face repetitive inquiries from field teams that require approval or explanations. The constant need to address these repetitive questions detracts from the PMM and PM's ability to concentrate on higher-level strategic initiatives, ultimately slowing down the sales cycle and affecting overall productivity and revenue."

Anyone who's worked in product marketing at scale recognizes this dynamic. You're hired to be strategic‚Äîto shape positioning, drive launches, enable sales teams with compelling narratives. Instead, you find yourself buried in email threads, Slack messages, and impromptu calls explaining the same concepts over and over. It's death by a thousand paper cuts.

Enter the Agentic AI Chatbot

Jacob Brass, a Product Marketing Manager in SAP's Business Data Cloud & Insights team, decided to tackle this problem head-on. He assembled a cross-functional team that brought together developers, designers, and domain experts from across the organization:

üßë‚Äçüíº

What they built wasn't just another FAQ bot or simple chatbot. They created what's increasingly being called an "Agentic AI"‚Äîan AI system capable of taking autonomous actions to complete tasks, not just answering questions. Their solution automates responses for SKU questions, solution capability inquiries, and even certain approval workflows.

"This isn't about replacing PMMs‚Äîit's about giving them their time back. The AI handles the repetitive queries so humans can focus on the work that actually requires human judgment."

Why This Matters for Product Marketing

The implications of this project extend far beyond SAP. It represents a template for how AI can transform the product marketing function‚Äînot by eliminating PMMs, but by dramatically amplifying their effectiveness.

Consider the math: If a PMM spends 2 hours a day answering repetitive field inquiries, that's 10 hours a week, or roughly 500 hours a year. That's 500 hours that could be spent on competitive intelligence, product launches, sales enablement content, or strategic planning. Multiply that across a team of 10 PMMs, and you're looking at 5,000 hours of reclaimed strategic capacity.

The Four Pillars of Impact

  • Reduced Operational Load: PMMs and PMs spend less time on repetitive inquiries
  • Faster, More Reliable Responses: Field teams get instant, consistent answers 24/7
  • Higher Quality Enablement: Consistent, accurate information every time
  • Scalable Foundation: A platform that can expand to handle more use cases over time

The Technology Behind the Transformation

What makes this implementation particularly interesting is how it integrates with SAP's existing systems. The chatbot doesn't operate in isolation‚Äîit connects to the SAP Harmony deal approval system, understanding the context of specific deals, SKUs, and approval requirements.

When a sales rep asks "Why is this deal flagged as Moderate Risk?", the AI can pull the relevant information from the system, explain the specific health exceptions that triggered the flag, and provide guidance on next steps. Previously, this would have required a PMM to log into the system, review the deal, and craft a response‚Äîa process that could take 15-30 minutes per inquiry.

The system handles three primary categories of inquiries:

  • SKU Questions: What's included in this SKU? Can these products be bundled? What's the pricing structure?
  • Solution Capability Inquiries: Does this solution support X use case? How does it integrate with Y system?
  • Approval Guidance: Why does this deal need approval? What information is required? Who needs to sign off?

Lessons for Every PMM Team

You don't need to be at SAP to apply these lessons. The pattern Jacob's team established is replicable:

1. Start with the Pain

Don't build AI for AI's sake. Identify the specific, repetitive tasks that consume disproportionate time. For Jacob's team, it was field inquiries. For your team, it might be competitive questions, pricing queries, or feature explanations.

2. Build Cross-Functionally

Notice that Jacob's team included developers, a UX designer, and domain experts. AI projects succeed when they combine technical capability with deep understanding of user needs. The PMM brings the domain expertise; the developers bring the technical chops; the designer ensures it's actually usable.

3. Integrate, Don't Isolate

The chatbot's power comes from its connection to existing systems. A standalone AI that can't access your CRM, your product database, or your deal system will have limited utility. The goal is augmented intelligence‚ÄîAI that makes your existing tools smarter.

4. Think Platform, Not Project

The team explicitly designed this as a "scalable support model" and "foundation for future automation." They're not just solving today's problem‚Äîthey're building infrastructure that can handle tomorrow's challenges.

The Bigger Picture

What Jacob Brass and his team have built is a concrete example of a larger shift happening across product marketing. We're moving from a world where PMMs are valued primarily for their knowledge (which can increasingly be encoded in AI systems) to one where they're valued for their judgment, creativity, and strategic thinking.

The PMMs who thrive in this new world won't be the ones who can answer SKU questions fastest‚Äîthey'll be the ones who can build systems like this, who can identify opportunities for AI augmentation, and who can focus their newly-freed time on work that genuinely requires human insight.

That's why Jacob's story matters. He didn't wait for IT to build this. He didn't wait for permission. He saw a problem, assembled a team, and built a solution. That's the kind of initiative that defines the future of product marketing.

Are You Building Something Similar?

We want to hear from PMM teams using AI to transform their work. Share your story and you could be our next User of the Week.

Congratulations to Jacob Brass and the entire team for showing what's possible when product marketing embraces AI‚Äînot as a threat, but as a force multiplier. You've given the rest of us a blueprint to follow.
